main_definition: In programming, a namespace is a container that holds a set of identifiers or names to organize code elements like classes, functions, variables, etc., avoiding naming conflicts.

meanings_and_examples.definition: Programming construct for grouping related items
meanings_and_examples.example: In C++, the namespace std contains all of the standard library's definitions. Example: using namespace std;

meanings_and_examples.definition: A concept in Visual Basic to organize code into logical units
meanings_and_examples.example: Defining a namespace 'MyApp' and encapsulating its classes, such as Customer and Order within it.

meanings_and_examples.definition: In file systems, a namespace is an extension of directory paths that help in locating files uniquely
meanings_and_examples.example: Windows uses drive letters like C: as namespaces for directories. Example: D: older ile.txt

meanings_and_examples.definition: A term used in software design patterns to group related classes and interfaces
meanings_and_examples.example: The Factory Method pattern can have a namespace 'CreationalPatterns' containing the factory method class.

meanings_and_examples.definition: In XML, namespaces are used to avoid name conflicts by qualifying element or attribute names with unique identifiers
meanings_and_examples.example: Defining an XML element like <book xmlns='http://example.com/books'>
